posts.name: A-Frame
posts.note: Creative Asian and international flavors mix at this hip eatery with communal tables and patio dining. You need to try the baby back ribs, and beer can chicken. If you're there on Sunday get the all-you-can-eat chicken which consists of three types of chicken, fries, corn, and Hawaiian buns.

posts.name: Azla Ethiopian Vegan
posts.note: Casual, cheery counter-serve with small tables specializing in vegan renditions of Ethiopian dishes.

posts.name: Belly and Snout
posts.note: Storefront space for inspired pork dishes featuring a variety of cuts amid basic decor. Belly and Snout serves up American twists on classic Filipino dishes at this Koreatown joint. Try the Sisig Hot Dog which is dressed up with sisig (a Filipino mixture of ground pork belly and pork snout, made in-house daily), in addition to garlic crema, pickled red onions, radishes, green onions, a fried egg and the Filipino citrus known as calamansi.

posts.name: Bludso's Bar & Que
posts.note: A sit-down outpost of a local Texas BBQ joint offering classic meats and sides, plus creative cocktails.

posts.name: Blue Star Donuts
posts.note: Minimalist cafe for grab-and-go brioche donuts in grown-up flavors such as blueberry-bourbon-basil and the best apple fritter I have ever had in my life and I'm in my mid 50's. Couldn't believe there is now a few Blue Star Donuts in the Los Angles area. You need to try one of their apple fritters, but any of their donuts will not steer you wrong.

posts.name: Chego West
posts.note: Spicy rice bowls and other Korean-Mexican eats. The humble little LA-in-a-rice bowl restaurant full of win and the color orange set out to reinvigorate the rice bowl. Slow roasted prime rib with creamed horseradish, or sticky-sweet slabs of Berkshire pork belly over hot rice and fried egg.

posts.name: chi SPACCA
posts.note: Meaty, upscale Italian fare from a trio of star chefs in a Tuscan atmosphere with worn-wood tables.

posts.name: Grand Central Market
posts.note: Emporium hosting food vendors and florists, plus game nights, movies and other events, since 1917.

posts.name: Horse Thief BBQ
posts.note: Grand Central Market window offering smoked meats and gourmet sides, plus outdoor seating. You need to order the smoked pork belly or the southern fried chicken sandwich.

posts.name: Intelligentsia Coffee
posts.note: High-end coffee bar chain serving daily roasted brews in an industrial-chic setting. They have a great dark chocolate hot chocolate and espresso (four shots). Great atmosphere to have a relaxing cup of coffe, tea, etc. while getting some work done or reading a book.

posts.name: Kogi BBQ
posts.note: Kogi BBQ first rolled out as the little Korean-taco-truck-that-could, peddling $2.00 Korean barbecue tacos on the streets of L.A. Little did they know that within a few short months, they would become an icon of LA street food, a roving symbol of rebellion, independence and the belief that excellent food can be had on a dime budget.

posts.name: La Brea Bakery Cafe
posts.note: Popular for its handmade bread, this casual cafe serves sandwiches, soup and other light fare.

posts.name: Leo's Tacos Truck
posts.note: Leo's Tacos Truck has delicious Al Pastor tacos are better than ever with a taste that will leave you wanting more. You can order them by the plate full which most people do. The beef head, tripe, lengua (tongue) etc. are outstanding too.

posts.name: Locol
posts.note: Conscientious fast-food spot with simple design for breakfast, burgers and health-oriented options.

posts.name: Monti Carlo
posts.note: Dive Bar in Koreatown.

posts.name: Myung in Dumplings
posts.note: Traditional Korean buns and dumplings offered in a simple, subdued eatery with a pictorial menu. They make some of the best dumplings I have ever eaten. My favorites were the spicy steam roll dumpling with pork, the boiled dumpling with pork, and the fried dumpling with shrimp.

posts.name: Original Pantry Cafe
posts.note: Casual cash-only diner, open since 1924, dishes up ample portions of American eats around the clock. You need to try the chicken fried steak or the pork chop breakfast specials if they have them.

posts.name: Osteria Mozza
posts.note: Lauded upscale Italian cuisine from chefs Nancy Silverton and Mario Batali in a bustling atmosphere.

posts.name: Pizzeria Mozza
posts.note: Nancy Silverton and Mario Batali turn out acclaimed wood-burning-oven pizzas and antipasti in busy digs.

posts.name: Salt and Straw
posts.note: Popular ice cream chain out of Oregon known for inventive flavors and farm-sourced ingredients. All their flavors are great it all depends on what you're in the mode to eat. My favorite is their Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons in a cup.

posts.name: Simmzy's
posts.note: Bustling, open-air pub with a rotating selection of craft beers and American eats, including burgers.

posts.name: Sunny Spot
posts.note: Colorful, funky, modern Caribbean joint, crafting inventive cocktails and jerk wings. It's another Roy Cho place.

posts.name: Super Tortas D.F.
posts.note: No-frills mobile eatery doling out Mexican tortas stuffed with layers of meats, cheese, and eggs. Found out about htis place while standing line for spit roasted al pastor.

posts.name: Swadeah
posts.note: Bare-bones establishment offering South Asian groceries and cafeteria-style Bangladeshi eats.

posts.name: Tavern On 2
posts.note: Lively gastropub offering farm-fresh bites and a rotating menu of 50 craft beers and wines in warm digs. The dish to order is pig tails.

posts.name: Tofu House (Beverly Soon Tofu)
posts.note: Traditional Korean dishes including more than 10 combinations of flavors of soon tofu, barbecued galbi, bulgogi, spicy chicken, spicy squid, tofu steak, and the stone plate bibimbap. You need to get the spicy tofu soup to put over rice.

posts.name: Venice Ramen
posts.note: Compact, simple Japanese eatery for housemade noodles in a range of broths, plus other specialties. No need for extra noodles since they give you so many to start with. The two types of dumplings are great too.
